The solution is not boiling but along with Sn(2+) goes to Sn(4+) you have water oxidation: 2H2O to form 4H(+) + O2 + 4e-. What you see are O2 bubbles evolving on the anode. Contrary to that Sn(2+) + 2e- gives Sn(0) should happen along with HER (hydrogen evolution reaction). Luckily, Sn, Pb, Hg, Cd are bad electrode materials for HER. In fact, they significantly shift the onset potential for HER so that it will happen only at much larger applied potential than what would normally happen on Pt, Au, Ni etc. electrodes. That's the reason why we used to use Hg in Polarography (you can even reduce alkaline metal ions to form amalgams on Hg droplet that serves as an electrode during the Polarographic experiment).

Safety first,DO NOT use lead tin solder, HCl will burn you, and the gases produced will be poisonous and explosive. If you have a basic knowledge of lab procedures it should be perfectly safe. A few suggestions, it is best to use a constant current power supply. I believe an LM 317 can provide that.(An LM 317 will make a power supply that is variable down to just below 2 volts. A good idea is to simply put a couple of high power (10 Amp) diodes in line with the output. that will drop the minimum output voltage to just about 0 to 20 volts.) And the voltage should be kept down to less than 2 volts. even then you are going to produce some hydrogen and chlorine gas, so you need fresh air. The slower you grow the crystal the closer to cubes they will become. the best i have been able to achieve are about like a pencil stub. With higher currents the crystal will grow out like tin feathers, and i mean they really look like a feather. Another suggestion is to use lead free plumber's solder as your source for tin. Then you can just use a 7 to 10 percent solution of HCL,( muratic acid). the tin will come off of the solder into solution and make the stannous cloride all by itself. Another problem with using pure tin cloride as your starting stock is that you will produce pure tin crystals. Pure tin has the nasty habbit of disintigrating into a grey dust in a few years. I have crystals made from lead free solder that are decades old. And they are still shiny. In conclution DO NOT use lead solder You will probably poison yourself. And yes you can do similar things with copper and silver but they are not as nice, in my oppinion, and i do not know any of the voltage or percentage requirements.

If you plan on doing more electrochemistry experiments may I suggest that you get a decent power supply. There are some decent power supplies on ebay (Chinese - Yihua brand) that can be set as either constant voltage or constant current. NB for most electrolysis involving metal salts you need a small voltage but a decent current.

There is no reason why it should hurt you when you touch electrodes from the laptop adapter! It produces voltage only 20 V and maximum output current is 4,5 V. This current would be deadly if it went through you, but in fact it can't. Your body works as resistor with capacity around 700k (you can measure it with your multimeter), so you can calculate the current going through your body like I = U/R = 20/700000 = 0,029 mA. It is really like nothing, you won't feel anything when you hold both electrodes in your hands when it is plugged into a socket. (You start to feel the DC going through you when it is about 2 mA, painful is 30 mA and deadly is around 40 mA.)

Let me explain this process too for curious people:

There are ions in the solution:
SnCl2 = Sn(2+) + 2Cl(-)
H2O = H(+) + OH(-)

Cathode means cations, there are free electrons there for "hungry" cations from cathode. Cations, not a cation. It means there is a hard rivalry there:
Sn(2+), H(+) => Sn(2+) and H(+) wins both, because Sn is a type of not so active metals like Na, but not so passive like Cu => we get metal and gas H2. But the second product is no so bright because Sn is more "passive" then Zn f.e. And Sn takes electrons more effective then Zn, and less electrons are leaving for H(+) as a result. But we can't ignore H2 in case of Sn.

Anode means anions, the anode takes electrons from anions. There is a hard rivalry too, but in case who will lose its own electrons:
Cl(–), OH(–) => Cl(–) weaker then "O" by electronegativity and Cl(–) loses its own electrons easer => we get gas Cl2. Oxygen is the second element after Fluorine by electronegativity. So I don't think that we have any traces of O2 as a product.

The growth of tin crystals (whisker) is a big problem in electronics manufacturing ever since the use of lead in tin/lead solder was forbidden. Unlike here the crystals grow spontaneously. It has nothing to do with the electric current. When a growing tin whisker touches a nearby circuit path it causes a bypass and the device fails.

Nile Red, I like your chemical videos very much, they are really interesting and informative.

Let me make some remarks for this experiment. If you use power supply, it's very desirable to connect a resistor consecutively with your electrolytic cell. If the cristals of tin grow large enough to touch both electrodes, there is a risk of short circuit.
In the electrolysis process tin chloride solution on the positive electrode (anode) dosen't boil. Besides of main reaction of oxydising Sn2+ to Sn4+, here take place side-reactions:
2Cl- -- 2e = Cl2
2H2O - 4e = 4H+ + O2
Thus, the gas produsing on the anode is basically chlorine with some oxygen.
